title: Rabies Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if:
bullets: The person is seriously injured in an animal attack.

items: The person is seriously injured in an animal attack.

sections.heading: 1. Stop Bleeding
bullets: Apply sustained pressure for several minutes.

items: Apply sustained pressure for several minutes.

sections.heading: 2. Clean Wound
bullets: Wash with clean water and gentle soap for 15 minutes.

items: Wash with clean water and gentle soap for 15 minutes.

sections.heading: 3. Gather Information About Animal
bullets: Notify the local health department or animal control about the animal's possible whereabouts.
If the animal is a pet, get the owner's contact information.

items: Notify the local health department or animal control about the animal's possible whereabouts.
If the animal is a pet, get the owner's contact information.

sections.heading: 4. See a Healthcare Provider Immediately
bullets: Do not wait for symptoms to appear.
If possible, bring information about the animal.
If the person was in an enclosed area with a bat, see a healthcare provider whether or not there is a bite wound. The person may have been bitten and not know it.

items: Do not wait for symptoms to appear.
If possible, bring information about the animal.
If the person was in an enclosed area with a bat, see a healthcare provider whether or not there is a bite wound. The person may have been bitten and not know it.

sections.heading: 5. Follow Up
bullets: If there is any risk of rabies infection, the healthcare provider will recommend anti-rabies treatment. This may include a series of shots.
The person may require a tetanus shot , depending on the date of the last shot.

items: If there is any risk of rabies infection, the healthcare provider will recommend anti-rabies treatment. This may include a series of shots.
The person may require a tetanus shot , depending on the date of the last shot.

sources: CDC: "Rabies: What Care Will I Receive?"
CDC: "Rabies Exposure: When Should I Seek Medical Attention?" "Learn About Bats and Rabies," and "What Type of Exposure Occurred?"
FamilyDoctor.org: "First Aid: Cuts, Scrapes and Stitches."
meta_description: WebMD tells you what to do if you've been bitten by an animal that may be carrying rabies.
